date: stated on April 8, 2019 in a legislative debate:
title: Is suicide the second cause of death among Missouri's youth?
text: The Republic of Tracy McCreery, D-St. Louis, raised concerns about the carrying of weapons on the campus on April 8, the debate in the House of Representatives on the House Bill 575. This bill, sponsored by the Republic, Dean Dorman, R-la Monté, was approved by the Senate on 25 April but was suspended before final approval was obtained. The draft law, which would allow some faculty and staff members on the campus to carry hidden weapons, is unlikely to go through this session. In the debate, McCreary said, "Suicide is the second leading cause of death among children between the ages of 15 and 19 and 25 and 34 in Missouri." McCreary said she wasn't supporting this bill because she believed that carrying firearms on campus would provide "more opportunities for people to commit suicide." We decided to take a closer look at McCreary's statement that suicide is the second leading cause of death among young people and adults in Missouri. The source of the statistics when we asked McCreary about her claim, referred to a fact sheet, a firearm suicide in the United States, published in August 2018 by an advocacy group in every town for gun safety. "This trend has been of particular concern to children and adolescents, with the firearms suicide rate rising by 61 per cent in the past 10 years," according to the Fact Sheet, which refers to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. She also said that she had found data for Missouri from the Ministry of Mental Health in Missouri. Check the facts (Kirk Cox) was mentioned on January 13, 2021 in a speech. By Warren Fisk: 20 January 2021, we found her data on a fact sheet, Suicide in Missouri: where we stand, published by the Missouri Institute of Mental Health Researchers, on behalf of the Ministry of Mental Health in Missouri, August 2017. It specifically states that suicide "is the second leading cause of death between 15-19 and 25-34 years of age." We were also able to find the latest fact sheet, published in August 2018. It continues to say that suicide is "the second leading cause of death in Missouri among young people/adults aged 10 to 24 in 2016," adding that suicide is the highest among young people aged 20 to 24. "Statistics speaks for themselves," said McCreary. "In Missouri, young people usually use guns to commit suicide. The data is very strong." How do you compare Missouri's statistics to other states? Information provided by the Missouri Institute of Mental Health also reveals useful information on the position of Missouri vis-à-vis other states. In Missouri, suicide rates are higher than national suicide rates. The State ranked 14th in the State at 18.33 (per 100,000 inhabitants), while the national rate was 13.42. "Missouri received several federal grants which offered programmes in schools and training in mental health agencies. It is one of a handful of states that received the so-called "zero suicide" grant, as Maureen Underwood, clinical counsel for the Adolescent Suicide Prevention Society, said. According to the CDC, suicide is also the second leading cause of death among young people and adults aged 10 to 34 in the United States in 2017. Intentional injury is the leading cause of death for the same age group. Our verdict said, "Suicide is the second leading cause of death among children between the ages of 15 and 19 and 25 and 34 in Missouri."
